Being a good steward with the money she receives, we are confident Marina will manage this loan efficiently and repay it in time.

Марина – розлучена, в неї є син. Для того, щоб забезпечити потреби родини, вона почала власний бізнес з продажу дитячого одягу на одному з місцевих ринків. Марина займається торгівлею в цій сфері вже понад 8 років. Її бізнес – єдине джерело прибутку для родини. Марина отримала першу позику від „Надії України” в 2002 році. З того часу вона сплатила 18 позик без жодних прострочень. Звичайно, бізнес Марини не одразу став успішним. Проте, її наполеглива важка праця допомогла їй зберегти стабільність власного бізнесу, навіть не дивлячись на діагноз рак та серйозну операцію, яку їй довелося перенести. Марина хотіла б збільшити власний робочий капітал, саме тому вона просить про позику в1200 доларів. Вона планує закупити дитячі светри, футболки, спіднички та шорти за оптовими цінами для подальшого роздрібного продажу. Позика не тільки допоможе їй придбати більше товарів та збільшити обсяги продажів, але й забезпечить краще життя для неї та її сина. Ми переконані, що вміння розумно витрачати отримані кошти допоможе Марині мудро використати цю позику та вчасно її сплатити.

loans.use: To increase sales stock

loans.name: Nji Alice

texts.en:
Born in 1965, Alice is a mother of three children. She faced difficulties with her mother-in-law and the death of her father when she was still young. To her, it was a dream come true when GHAPE extended outreach into her community and the problem of inadequate capital disappeared as she received her first loan in 2005. With her previous loans, she provided her community with pork, manure, and yams. Her goal is to build her self-esteem and provide for her children.

Given a loan of $400, she plans to reinforce her pig fence and buy piglets, pig feed, and medication. She plans to repay her loans from farming activities with manure from her pig farm and to make savings in her pigs. She is convinced that her business will succeed because of her skills in the domain, the available market, and the support from her group and center members.

She plans to pay her loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: production of piglets and fattening of pigs for pork

loans.name: Dodo

texts.fr:
Mrs. Dodo K. was born in 1968 in Lomé, in the Gulf prefecture of Togo. She is married and mother of one child; she is also responsible for two other people. She sells used refrigerators and freezers, etc. to people in her part of town. Her husband is abroad, leaving her financially responsible for the family.

Mrs. K. is requesting a loan of $1000 so that she can buy her products directly at the port and satisfy the needs of her customers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Madame K. Dodo est née en 1968 à Lomé dans la préfecture du Golfe. Elle est mariée et mère d’un (1) enfant et deux (2) personnes à sa charge. Elle fait le commerce des réfrigérateurs et des congélateurs d’occasion dans son quartier. Son mari qui est à l’étranger ce qui fait que toutes les charges se reposent sur elle.

Elle sollicite un apport financier de $1000 pour s’approvisionner elle-même au port et satisfaire les demandes du marché.

loans.use: selling appliances

loans.name: Khan

texts.en: Mrs. Khan S. M. is 26 years old, a mother of two children, and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She and her husband work on her farmland growing crop, earning around $6 each day .and two of her children attend school. Eventually, this couple hopes to use this loan to purchase a grinding machine to assist in grinding their crop faster, easier and more efficiently.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy products in bulk

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Ros (age 59) was married in 1965 and has seven children, six sons and one daughter. She is currently in the business of weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor in 1960 and began her silk production in the same year. Her husband, Mr. Ry Sok (age 62) is a farmer. Five of her children are married and live in separate houses from her.

Ros has borrowed money from MAXIMA five times before. Now she is requesting a loan to continue her weaving business in the amount of $100. She will use this money to purchase silk materials for preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use:
To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for 
selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Susitina

texts.en: Susitina is 36 years old and has three children. She has applied for a $300 loan to buy fertilizers and tools to use on her plantation. Three days a week, she sells her produce at the local market, earning about $72 a day. She uses this money to meet her family's needs, especially those of her children. In the future, she hopes to apply for another loan which she would like to use to build a small house on the plantation, so she can keep her crops safe from thieves. She enjoys her work, especially because of the support it allows her to provide to her family.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and tools to use on a farm

loans.name: Lugoba B 2022(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Emily T.. She is currently in the business of operating a clinic and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to improve the clinic's business.

Emily is 36 years old and is married. She has 1 child, aged 6, who goes to school. Each week, Emily makes approximately UGX 30,000 in profit. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to save money and construct rental houses/quarters.

Emily is joined in her small group by Cate M., N. Jalia, Sarah N., and Sicola N.. Cate M. is currently in the business of poultry farming and is requesting a loan of UGX 900,000 to purchase poultry feed.

N. Jalia is currently in the business of selling used clothing and is requesting a loan of UGX 300,000 to increase the stock of clothes.

Sarah N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan of UGX 300,000 to add to the business.

Sicola N. is currently in the business of selling fruit and is requesting a loan of UGX 300,000 to expand her business and start selling vegetables too.

loans.use: To improve her business

loans.name: Kulwa

texts.en: Kulwa is 27 years old and is married with one 2-year-old child. She and her husband also take care of  another child of the same age. Kulwa has been a soft drinks seller since 2005. Every day, she works from 7am to 12pm at her business.  Kulwa now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Lisania Karm

texts.en:
Lisania Karm M. T. helps run a family carpentry business making custom furniture and doors in the city of Pucallpa, in the Ucayali region of Peru. Lisania does the majority of the buying and selling, while her husband is a skilled carpenter. They have invested in different woods, mainly capiona and cimilla.

Lisania is 24 years old with one child and is happily married. She loves working with her family, building relationships, and making deals with her clients. Lisania has experience selling clothing and chickens in the main market of Pucallpa. Her goals are to educate her children and continue to grow the business.

A member of the community bank Fray Martin, Lisania is requesting a loan of $725 to repay over four months. She will use the loan to purchase more wood and cover some operational expenses. She recognizes that purchasing modern tools would help the family business as well.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and cover some operational expenses

loans.name: Ericka Francisca

texts.es:
Erika E.’s occupation is in the field of education, being that she is an elementary school teacher in a small school in the municipality of Villanueva in the city of Chinandega. She is the mother of two school-aged daughters who she has to maintain and offer the necessary conditions to subsist. For this reason, she is looking for the means to reconstruct her house being that it has suffered considerable damage over the years due to the effects of natural phenomena.

To proceed with the reconstruction of her home, it is necessary to emphasize that she had already initiated this project, but when she lacked funds, she decided to wait some time until she obtained the money required to finish the reconstruction. For this, she has sought refuge in Ceprodel to obtain the necessary funds that will allow her to purchase materials and continue with the reconstruction of her home, which she has invested so much in.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La labor a la que se dedica la señora Erika E. es a la docencia siendo maestra de primaria en un pequeño colegio de la ciudad de Chinandega del municipio de Villanueva. Es madre de dos hijas en edad escolar que tiene la obligación de mantener y proporcionarle las condiciones necesarias para subsistir. Para ello busca la manera de cómo reconstruir su casa de habitación ya que a través de los años ha venido sufriendo el desgaste físico proporcionado por los fenómenos naturales.

Para llevar a cabo la reconstrucción de su vivienda es necesario destacar que primeramente había iniciado esta labor pero al hacerle falta al recurso económico decidió esperar un momento para obtener el dinero para continuar con la reconstrucción de su casa. Para ello ha buscado refugio en Ceprodel para obtener el crédito necesario que le permita obtener los materiales para continuar con la reconstrucción de su vivienda que tanto ha invertido en ella.

loans.use: Purchase materials for the reconstruction of her home.

loans.name: Sarvinoz

texts.en:
G. Sarvinoz is 19 years old and lives with her parents. In the past, she was helping her mother with her business of selling clothes. As she has always liked sales, it went well and she decided to open her own business.

Sarvinoz has been a market vendor for 3 years already. She sells underclothes for women in the local market, “Korvon”, in Dushanbe. Through these years, she managed to make her business stable and profitable, generating a stable income for her family, and allowing her to support her parents, brother and sister.

Now, Sarvinoz is planning to expand her business and in order to do so, she’ll need to increase her working capital for purchasing new, modern underclothes for women. From the profit of her business, she wants to buy her dearest brother a bicycle, which he has been dreaming about for a long time. With this purpose in mind, Sarvinoz requests $1000 US for a term of 12 months. She promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all for supporting her. Let’s get behind this loving sister to make her little brother’s dream come true. Your support will really help her.

loans.use: Purchasing new goods for selling in order to expand the business

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is married, and lives with her husband. She sells gari (milled and fried cassava) in the local market. She has been doing so for the past 8 years. She travels to nearby villages in order to purchase more products and sell them to earn income. Lydia would like a loan to ensure that her prices remain stable. Farmers are about to enter the lean season, which would lead to a high price of cassava. Lydia believes that this loan would allow her to support her family and expand her business.

Lydia is a member of a group called Queens. Members support one another in repaying loans.

loans.use: To more bags of “Gari” (milled and fried cassava)

loans.name: Gaudensia's Tupendane Group

texts.en:
Gaudensia is married with two children aged 21 and 18 years old. She also takes care of someone who is 57 years old. She has owned a small grocery store since 2004. Every day she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and earns a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Gaudensia now hopes for a loan to buy more grocery items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members who also have businesses selling clothing, vegetables, and charcoal.

loans.use: To increase her grocery store inventory

loans.name: Tural

texts.en: Tural was born in 1983. He lives in Khachmaz town. This young man is single. He has been in the auto repair business for 2 years. Now this young man needs a loan of  US$ 1200 to buy the necessary spare parts and tools  for improving his business. He has a lot of clients and he wants to improve his business so as to provide his clients with the best service.

loans.use: to buy the necessary spare parts and tools  for improving his business

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel T. is single and has no children. He has been schooled through the junior high level. Since 2006, Samuel has made a living selling bicycle parts at Kissi station near Elmina. He uses his income to pay utility bills and other expenses. Samuel will use the loan to increase his capital and buy more bicycle parts to sell. With the new profits from his business, he plans to complete work a building he is constructing.

loans.use: Samuel will use the loan to increase his capital and buy more bicycle parts to sell.

loans.name: Rubina's Group

texts.en:
Rubina baji is the wife of T. M. and they live in Yadgar in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house, where she has lived for 19 years. She is the mother of ten children: five sons and five daughters. Three sons are house painters. The others are free and don’t do anything. Her daughters stay at home and do household work.

Rubina baji is a seamstress and sews clothes to order. Her daughters help her cut out the dresses. Rubina baji successfully repaid her previous two loans from Asasah. She requests a loan to buy another sewing machine so that she can complete the previous orders more quickly and get new orders.

She has several other members in her loan group. Rehana baji requests a loan to buy seasonal fruits to resell. Naziran baji wants a loan to buy clothes to resell. Samina baji requests a loan to buy paint brushes to resell.

loans.use: Buy another sewing machine to product dresses more quickly

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia A. is married and has two children. She has received schooling through the primary level. Lydia sells used clothing, towels and bed sheets at Abura market, which she has done since 1999. Her husband is a pensioner. Lydia uses her income to assist her husband in providing the basic needs of the family. Lydia will use the loan as an additional capital to buy more bails of used clothing, towels, bed sheets and other items. With the new profits from her expanded business, Lydia plans to save towards building a family house she has planned to do with her husband.

loans.use: Lydia will use the loan to buy more bails of used clothing, towels, bed sheet and other items to resell.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia is a member of the Sumaq Huayta Village Bank; “Sumaq Huayta” means “Beautiful Flower” in Quechua. Sonia is 36 years old and is married with one child. Sonia sells different kinds of sweets from the door of her home, which is near a school. She works everyday. She also travels to regional markets, where she buys cheese and garlic. She sends the cheese to Lima for her sister to sell there, and she peels the garlic and sells it by the kilogram. Sonia needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy cheese and sweets. Sonia dreams of improving her home, improving her business, and that her son will grow up to be a good, working professional.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow Sonia es socia del Banco Comunal Sumaq Huayta que significa Linda Flor.

Sonia es casada, tiene 36 años y 1 hijo, Sonia vende golosinas variadas, actividad que realiza en la puerta de su casa, todos los días, su casa esta ubicada cerca de un colegio. Además viaja a las ferias de la regio en donde compra quesos y ajo, los quesos lo envía a Lima a su hermana para que lo comercializa y los ajos los pela y lo vende por kilos.

Sonia necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de quesos y golosinas. Sonia sueña con mejorar su casa, mejorar su negocio y que su hijo sea un buen profesional.

loans.use: Buy cheese and sweets

loans.name: Salwa

texts.en: Salwa is a 54-year-old married woman with 6 children, living in Kitermaya-Al Chouf in Mount Lebanon. She opened her shop in 2005, and now she is serving her village in addition to the neighboring villages. Salwa wants to buy clothing at a very good price, so she can increase her profit; therefore she is asking for a loan of US$ 1000.

loans.use: Buy clothes in a good price

loans.name: Yussy Luisa

texts.es:
Yussy es socia del Bancomunal Medalla Milagrosa.
Yussy  es madre soltera, tiene 26 años una hija de 4 años, esta en el jardín.  
Yussy no termino el colegio por que no le gustaba estudiar, quiso dedicarse a trabajar. 
Se dedico a vender en las calles desde los 18 años,, intento  trabajando en casa haciendo de todo pero lo dejo  por que ganaba poco, entonces volvió nuevamente a vender en las calles,  helados y habas. Mientras que ella trabaja en tiempos de verano deja a su hija en casa de una amiga, quien la cuida todo el día,  y a las siete de la noche Yussy  recoje a su hija.
Desde que esta en Finca, ha sido una ayuda, tiene capital para comprar mercadería.  
Necesita un crédito de 1200 soles, para comprar helados y habas. 
El sueño que tiene Yussy es tener un negocio de venta  caldo de gallina.
texts.en:
Yussy is a member of the Miraculous Medal Community Bank. Yussy is a single mother, 26 years old, has a 4 year old daughter who is in pre-school. Yussy did not finish high school because she did not like studying. She wanted to start working. Since she was 18 years old, she been a traveling street sales woman. She tries to work out of her home but she had to give it up because she did not make enough income. She then returned to selling goods throughout the streets, such as ice creams and beans. While she works in the summer time, she leaves her daughter at home with a friend who takes care of her all day. At seven at night, Yussy picks up her daughter. Since she has been with FINCA, she has had help and capital to purchase merchandise. She needs a loan of 1,200 soles to buy ice creams and beans. Her dream is to have her own business selling chicken soup.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: 1,200 soles to buy ice creams and beans

loans.name: Rabia

texts.en:
Rabia baji has been a citizen of a city called Kot Radha Kishan for the past 15 years. Kot Radha Kishan is famous for its livestock because mostly people do this business to support their families. Rabia baji’s husband's name is Z. I. and he is a wood seller. He has been selling wood for the past 10 years. He chose this work because people used to come to him to buy wood to burn in their stoves for cooking meals for their families.

Rabia baji helps her husband by selling wood in the community. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more wood to sell.

loans.use: To buy wood to sell

loans.name: Kodirjon

texts.en:
K. Kodirjon is a diligent and tenacious farmer who strives to provide for his family. His wife does not work, so he carries the burden of meeting his family's needs alone through his farming income. He works on a one-hectare farm owned by his parents. His harvests are sometimes not maximized because his cultivation method and seeds are not the best. Better farming supplies, seeds and fertilizer require more capital, which he doesn't have. Kodirjon is relieved that IMON International will help him get the loan he needs to improve his farm. This loan will be used to buy superior seeds, organic fertilizers and pesticides. Kodirjon is waiting for his next harvest, which he hopes will yield better results than his previous harvests. He will use his farming income to support his children’s educational needs, and if there is still some money left, he really hopes to fix his unfinished house.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is 45 years old and married with 5 children. She sells crates of eggs and she has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more crates of eggs to sell. She hopes to expand this business. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase eggs

loans.name: Lulu

texts.en: Lulu S., 37 is married with two children.  She has two years of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the villagers and public, six days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 340 tala .  SPBD loans are Lulu’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of sugar and flour, cooking oil, plastic bags and a big frying pan

loans.name: Femmes Commerçantes 5 Group

texts.fr: Les 5 femmes membres du groupe sont unies par le bon voisinage depuis longtemps. Elles sont dans un groupe fédéral de toutes les femmes de la commune de Thiès. C'est le groupement qui a été subdivisé en groupe de 5 pour faciliter la gestion. Les groupes sont créés par affinité par les femmes elles-mêmes. Elles mènent diverses activités génératrices de revenus et soutiennent leurs maris dans la prise en charges de leur famille respective. Le groupe s'autofinançait par une tontine interne mais avec le crédit de l'IMCEC il trouve des moyens plus importants et un délai court pour le financement de leurs activités. La plupart d’entre elles ont des étalages au marché central de Thiès commune ou elles vendent légumes, poisson, bijoux, tissus, etc.
texts.en:
The five women members of the group have been united for a long time by a good neighborhood. They are in a federal group of all the women in the community of Thiès. It's an association subdivided into groups of five in order to facilitate the managing of it. The groups are created by affinity among the women themselves. The women do a diversity of income-generating work and support their husbands in providing for their respective families. The group used to finance itself through an internal tontine (a traditional community revolving savings and loan group), but with the loan from IMCEC, greater funding along with shorter terms may be gotten for their businesses. Most of the group members have a display of goods at the central market of Thiès, where they sell vegetables, fish, jewelry, cloth, etc.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy local products in the weekly rural marketplaces and fishing areas to be sold in town

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a native from Cabgan, a small village situated across the island. Their place is an Island that separates from the mother barrio named Punta Miray, Baliangao, Mis. Occ. The member has to ride with a motorized pumpboat for at least 5 to 10 minutes to attend a weekly center meeting in Punta Miray.

Florence is married with 6 children. Most of the children are still school age. She has availed herself of her 10th loan cycle worth 10,000 pesos for the repairs of their existing house. Their main source of income is from fishing. Mrs. M., as shown in the picture, is seated in the middle with their house that has been in the process of repairs now. She hopes that they can always have a good catch so they can cope with their obligations with Paglaum.

loans.use: To purchase materials for house repairs

loans.name: Temitope

texts.en: Temitope sells phone recharge cards in large quantities as she has a printing machine, and also runs a viewing center. She has been in these businesses for over three years now and needs a loan of N140,000 to purchase more phone recharge cards and DVD tapes, and to improve the video club viewing center. Temitope is 35 years old, married to I. (a fashion designer) and they have three children. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more phone recharge cards and DVD tapes

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine A. sells earrings, panties and mother care products in Hohoe central market. Christine has received a junior high education.  She is married and has three children. Her loan will be used to buy more of the mother care products to sell. She hopes to reinvest the new profits.

..."mother care" in Ghana offers ongoing support for newborns and mothers...

loans.use: Buy more mother care products to sell.

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en: Maricar R. is an entrepreneur who lives with her husband and three school-aged children in a coastal slum community north of Manila. She owns and manages a grocery store located in front of her house. Maricar has been an itinerant entrepreneur for six years. Out of her desire to move out of poverty, she worked hard at earning her customers' respect. She later owned and is now managing a small apartment which she rents out to transients. She earns Php 30,000 from the combined proceeds of the apartment rental and accumulated net sales from her grocery store. Her fervent prayer is for God to sustain her children's education through the blessings that He entrusted to her. Maricar has just finished repaying her previous loan of PHP 10,000 from CCT. She has applied for a new loan to purchase additional merchandise, like charcoal (fuel), cooking oil, and other grocery items to sell in her store. A woman with a compassionate heart, Maricar dreams of converting her small grocery store into a big supermarket someday where she can offer goods at fairly low prices to consumers and at the same help many people land a job. About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal, oil, and groceries for her store

loans.name: Liza

texts.en:
Liza V. is from the village of Cabunga-an, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 38 years old. Liza is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Liza owns & operates a business selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Liza has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 1000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Liza joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Liza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. Liza is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Liza from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is fifty – two years old. She is married and has given birth to six children, three sons and one daughter who are all still in school. Margaret works very hard to support her husband to provide for the family. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in Oda in the Eastern region of Ghana. She is a food vendor. She runs a chop bar in her community. Margaret prepares and sells all kinds of local dishes. She procures her raw materials from nearby towns at moderate prices. She has been in business for over fifteen years now and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to expand her business.
To buy second hand textiles

loans.use: To buy food stuffs

loans.name: Lan

texts.en: Lan Thị Đỗ was born in 1960. She lives in Xóm Chợ, Uy Nỗ, Đông Anh, Hà Nội with her son’s family. Her husband has been dead for a long time. She has two small grandsons. Mrs. Lan has a store. Her son is a bicycle mechanic. Together they sell bicycle parts. They have an income of about 5,000,000 VND.  She would like to borrow 6,322,000 VND to buy bicycle parts to sell.

loans.use: To buy bicycle parts to sell

loans.name: Esaaf

texts.en: Isaaf is very hardworking and enterprising widow woman. She’s 63-year-old and living with her daughter. She works as a home-based cooker since 1995 where she preparing special food upon request of clients. Today, Issaf is applying for a loan of $1,000 to buy additional merchandise shop to meet the requirement of her clients and make a good income.

loans.use: buy additional merchandise

loans.name: Las Intelectuales 3 Group

texts.en:
Rosa is the coordinator of the group called "Las Intelectuales" (The Intellectuals). Her story is representative of both her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients, many of whom recently emigrated from Haiti to the DR. Her group is based in the area surrounding La Romana, an agricultural area where the economy focuses around the sugar cane harvest, where running water is unreliable and not potable, and electricity are unreliable at best. Here she makes her home as a single mother with her two children.

If you have ever wondered where clothing that the Salvation Army cannot sell ends up, Rosa's business can provide part of the answer. Rosa intends to use the money to buy "paca de ropa" or packages of  used clothes, which are sold in bulk after being shipped to the DR from wealthier countries. She intends to use her first loan to invest in this business and sell the clothes in her neighborhood. Its a good business and she expects the profits to allow her to provide for her children's school supplies and to keep expanding her business. She thanks all of you for your support.

loans.use: To buy packages of used clothes in bulk to sell

loans.name: Abdul Basher

texts.en:
A. Basher is the son of A. M.. He is married and has 5 children, three sons and two daughters. His youngest son is a college student, in first year and the others are students at school. He has a mobile phone sales shop in the city of Kabul and he needs a small loan for his business to become strong and to help with his family.

He is requesting an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani. He wants to expand and develop his business. He wants to buy more mobile phones and to complete the stock of inventory for his shop and to work hard.

He is very happy to have this process of small loans in Afghanistan and especially wants to thank the Kiva lenders around the world for this process.

loans.use: Towards expanding his business.

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua trades in game meat. She is a 29-year-old married mother of two children who are both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a community dominated by farming in the Western Region of Ghana. Most of the dwellers practice farming alongside other trading activities. Akua buys smoked game meat from nearby communities and sells at the local market. Akua says she also supplies food vendors in her community. She has been in business for eight years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy game meat

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
Felisa T. is from the village of Ibung Villa Verde, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 53 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Felisa owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month. In 2007, Felisa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Felisa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her fifth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es:
En el municipio de San Rafael del Sur, la señora Luz G. se dedica desde hace nueve años al negocio de venta de ropa la que comercializa ambulantemente en una comarca llamada San Pablo donde visita a varias personas con el fin de vender la ropa para llevar el sustento a su casa.

Este negocio por ser ambulante, muchas veces se expone a la fatiga del sol y a recibir la lluvia pero a pesar de esto ella sigue trabajando porque está comprometida con el bienestar de su familia. El crédito lo solicita para invertirlo en la compra de la ropa y también en la compra de sandalias para comercializarlas en su localidad.
texts.en:
In the municipality of San Rafael del Sur, Luz G. has worked for nine years in her business selling clothes. She sells them as a traveling salesperson in a county named San Pablo, where she visits various people, offering clothes for sale in order to support her household. Because her business involves walking, she is often exposed to rain or becomes tired in the sun, but in spite of this, she keeps working because she is committed to her family's well-being. She is requesting a loan so she can invest the funds in purchasing clothes as well as sandals to sell in her area.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing clothes to sell

loans.name: Margot Andrea

texts.es:
Margot A. D. de 45 años de edad vive en casa propia junto con sus hijas; de las cuales una de ellas trabaja y le apoya tambien en su negocio de ropa.
Viven en Las Colinas – Subtanjalla, fueron afectadas por el terremoto y poco a poco han ido recuperando sus bienes.
Trabajaba como obrera de campo y tambien como trabajadora del hogar. Es una mujer luchadora que ha sacado adelante a sus hijas; ahora se dedica a la venta de ropa en forma recorredora de martes a domingos en el mercado toledo desde hace 8 meses.
Ella desea el crédito para invertir mas en su negocio con ropa de verano y asi poder obtener un mejor ingreso ya que ella desea brindarles a sus hijas una educación superior que les permita seguir adelante.
texts.en:
Margot A. D., 45, lives in her own house with her daughters. One of them works and also helps her in her clothing business. They live in Las Colinas – Subtanjalla. They were affected by the earthquake, and, little by little, they have been recovering their assets. She worked as a field worker, and she also did domestic work. This woman is a fighter, and she has gotten her daughters ahead. For eight months now she has been selling clothes from Tuesday through Sunday at the Toledo Market. She wants the loan to invest more in her business with summer clothes. That way she will be able to get more income. She wishes to give her children a university education that will allow them to succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Businge Nakayisigi Caroline Group

texts.en:
Caroline N., 48, is a businesswoman. She is married with eight children and she also looks after two siblings who are schooling. She has been in the foodstuff trade for over one year. 

She is using the loan to purchase items like cassava and sweet potatoes from gardens for sale. The loan is helping her add capital by stocking at least three to four bags of foodstuffs. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to earn a living.

loans.use: To purchase items like cassava and sweet potatoes from gardens to sell

loans.name: Julieta's Group

texts.en:
Julieta V. is from the village of Mocag, Baggao, Cagayan. She is 48 years old and the leader of a 13-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Julieta is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Julieta has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2009, Julieta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Oswalda

texts.es:
Oswalda tiene 50 años, es una mujer entregada al trabajo, pues desde que se separó de su pareja tuvo que afrontar sola la alimentación y educación de sus 3 hijos, ahora dos de ellos ya son mayores e independientes, por aun cuida del menor. 

Desde su infancia ha trabajado arduamente, por lo que quedarse sola a cargo de sus hijos no le fue muy difícil. Anteriormente se era vendedora ambulante y con las ganancias que captó logró construir su casa propia, donde instaló una tienda de comestibles. Es así que desde hace 8 años se dedica a la atención de su tienda donde también vende verduras y frutas, pues con éstas gana más que con los abarrotes. Por ello, tres veces a la semana, se levanta a las 3 de la madruga para ir de compras al mercado mayorista y adquirir las frutas y demás productos. A Oswalda le gusta vender, esta actividad la mantiene muy entretenida y conversa con sus clientes, además en algunas oportunidades sus hijos la apoyan y eso la reconforta mucho. 

Este es su octavo crédito con MFP, por lo que ratifica su compromiso de pagar sus cuotas en las fechas señaladas. Asimismo, señala que trabaja en armonía con sus compañeras grupo. Con el dinero que esta vez solicita piensa comprar útiles escolares y venderlos en su bodega para aprovechar la campaña escolar y captar nuevos clientes.
texts.en:
Oswalda is 50 years old and is a woman who is devoted to her work. Since separating from her partner, she was faced with providing food and education to her 3 children. Now two of them are older and independent, but she still cares for the younger one.

She has worked arduously since she was young, so having to care for her children on her own was not very difficult for her. She was previously a door-to-door saleswoman and with her earnings, she was able to build her own house where she set up a grocery store. This is how, for the past 8 years, she has been working in her store where she also sells fruits and vegetables, since she earns more with these than with the groceries. She wakes up at 3am three times per week to go shopping at the wholesale market and purchase fruits and other products. Oswalda likes selling because it keeps her entertained and she talks with her customers. Her children also help her sometimes and that comforts her a lot.

This is her eighth loan with MFP, which confirms her commitment to making her loan repayments on the assigned dates. It also shows that she works in harmony with her fellow group members. With this loan that she is requesting, she plans to purchase school supplies and sell them in her store to take advantage of the beginning of school and attract new customers.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase desk supplies to sell in her store

loans.name: Simon

texts.en:
Simon is a 62-year-old married man in western Kenya, near the town of Kitale. He has eight children, ranging in age from 7 to 29, with the four youngest all attending school.

Simon has been involved in farming for over thirty years now, and earns most of his income from selling maize and beans. The main challenge he has faced lately is droughts that have made farming difficult.

Simon has a successful relationship with Juhudi Kilimo, having proved his creditworthiness by satisfying past loans. He has now requested this loan for Kes 30,000 to expand his poultry farming operations. He says that the extra income from this loan will help ensure a stable income, now and in the near future.

Simon has plans for expansion in the next five to ten years, and he hopes that with his solid credit history he will be able to access more capital when necessary. He is hopeful that standards of living for himself and his family will continually improve over time.

loans.use: To expand his poultry project

loans.name: Raquel

texts.es:
Raquel tiene 28 años de edad, es madre soltera y vive junto a su menor hijo de dos años de edad en casa de sus padres, ubicada en el distrito de Zaña, a 45 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

La necesidad de sacar adelante a su menor hijo hizo que sintiera la necesidad de iniciar un negocio que le permitiera obtener ingresos con los que pueda salir adelante. Por eso decicidó instalar una bodega en casa de sus padres desde hace dos años. Empezó vendiendo pocos productos y poco a poco, gracias a su esfuerzo, el negocio ha ido creciendo; actualmente ofrece abarrotes, productos de belleza, ropas para damas y caballeros, gaseosas y cerveza, entre otros. La variedad de productos que ofrece y el buen trato que brinda hacen que su negocio tenga mucha acogida.

Raquel desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de mercadería de manera que pueda satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes y también obtener mas ingresos que le permitan seguir adelante y apoyar a los gastos de su hogar. Por ello se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su objetivo.

Ella es una mujer bastante trabajadora y que ha luchado por salir adelante a pesar de su condición de madre soltera, sus vecinos y conocidos le consideran una persona responsable y de confianza.
texts.en:
Raquel is a 28 year old single mother. She lives with her two year old son in her parents’ house. It is located in the Zaña district, which is 45 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. The need to get her minor son ahead made her feel the need to start a business, which would allow her to get income to get ahead. Therefore, two years ago she decided to set up a convenience store in her parents’ house. She started selling a few products, and thanks to her efforts, the business has been slowly growing. She currently sells groceries, beauty products, women’s and men’s clothing, soft drinks, and beer, among other things. The variety of products she sells and the good service she offers make her business very well received. Raquel wishes to expand her business by purchasing merchandise so that she can satisfy her customers’ demand. She also wants to get more earnings that will allow her to get ahead and help with the household expenses. That is why she has seen the need of asking Edpyme Alternativa, for the first time, for a loan for 1,500 PEN. This will help her achieve her objective. She is a very hard-working woman who has fought to get ahead in spite of being a single mother. Her neighbors and acquaintances consider her to be a responsible and trustworthy person.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise to expand her convenience store

loans.name: Jimmy

texts.en: Jimmy is 30 years old and is married with two children. He runs an auto spare parts shop to earn a living. He previously was working in his father’s workshop before he started his own business. He is a very hardworking person. He is grateful to Faulu Kenya for the training they offered him. He acquired customer care skills and learned how to keep business records, and his business has tremendously grown. He hopes to expand his business and improve his living standards in the future. He has requested for a loan of KES 20,000 to buy more spare parts for sale.

loans.use: To buy more auto spare parts

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a faithful and hard-working businessman who sells groceries to his customers. He is a 20 year old single man. He spends most of his time taking care of his work. He trades in groceries like candies, mineral water, toiletries, canned food, biscuits, beverages (juices and soft drinks) and so on. He has operated the shop for the past 2 years, but when he was younger, since he took after his father, he used to help him. Therefore, he gained lots of experience and knows how to please his clients, which makes him successful in his groceries sales. He plans to use the loan to purchase more stock of groceries to serve his customers. This is the first time that he has requested a loan.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of groceries.

loans.name: Mercedes Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Mercedes es una mujer de iniciativa, de edad de 38 años, se dedica a la venta de enchiladas, el cual es una ayuda para apoyar  a sus hijos con los gastos ya que su esposo es jubilado y no tiene otros beneficios. Tiene años de estar negociando, sus ventas anteriores era la venta de cosméticos pero le atrasaban mucho el Dinero lo que le motivo cambiar a comida ya que se vende diario y efectivo. Con sus préstamos ha logrado las mejoras a su casa, con este financiamiento lograra terminar el cuarto que comenzó con el crédito anterior ya que le falta repellar, embaldosar, poner techo, puertas para poder hacer uso de el. lo que será de gran comodidad y privacidad.
texts.en:
Mercedes, age 38, is a woman with initiative. She sells enchiladas. This is a help in paying her children’s expenses. Her husband is retired, and he does not have other benefits. She has been in business for years. She previously sold cosmetics, but she got very behind with the money. This motivated her to change to food, which she sells daily and for cash. She has used the loans to make improvements on her house. With this loan she will finish the room she started with the previous loan. The room needs to be plastered and tiled. It needs a roof and doors to be usable. This will provide great comfort and privacy.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction material like sand, cement, zinc, and beams to finish enclosing the room

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.es:
La Socia pertenece al banco comunal “COLQUECANCHA”; Nuestra Socia vive en la comunidad de Raqchi perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba del departamento de Cusco.

Nuestra socia es la Sra. Luz marina, Nuestra socia tiene 26 años de edad, la socia es casada y tiene 2 menores hijos, Nuestra socia alterna sus diferentes actividades del hogar con el comercio minorista y la artesanía, la socia junto a su esposo tienen un pequeño terreno de cultivo de maíz y papa, ella vende los productos secos y también se dedica a hacer a mano con lanas de colores pulseras con diseños andinos y recrea toda la iconografía Inka; Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para comprar sus materiales y parte de ello para comprar aves de corral. 

Nuestra socia agradece a todos los inversionistas que hacen  posible la realización de este sueño y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Luz Marina belongs to the Colquecancha community bank; she lives in the Raqchi community, Urubamba, Cusco. She is 26, married, and has 2 young children. She does housework, retail and handicrafts, and she and her husband own a small plot of land where they grow corn and potatoes. She sells these products and also makes handmade bracelets with Andean designs and Incan iconography. Luz Marina is requesting this loan to buy materials and barnyard birds. She is grateful to all of the investors who are making this dream possible, and promises to repay the loan on time.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Craft materials and barnyard fowl

loans.name: Rahima Akbar Group

texts.en:
Kamila is the daughter of A. R.. She is 52 years old and the leader of Rahima A. group. She is married and the mother of seven children. She lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. Her youngest son has a cart of dried fruit in the city of Kabul. Kamila wants to take a loan for her son. He wants to buy more dry fruit such as almonds and raisins for his cart.

Therefore, his mother (Kamila) has a requested a loan for her son to buy the necessary things for his cart.

loans.use: to buy more dried fruit like almonds and raisins for her son's cart

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a single mother of three children who all go to school.  She doesn’t take care of any additional family. She goes door to door selling second-hand clothes.   She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. Margaret buys bales of second-hand clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda, and uses public transport to and from shopping. She has been in this business for five years.  

Besides this clothing business she also owns a poultry farm at her home.  Her customers are the local people, and she works six days a week. Her business challenge is the rainy season which hinders her movements.  She aspires to getting a permanent business premise.  She joined MCDT because she wanted additional capital to boost her business. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house, which has neither electricity nor piped water.  Her monthly expenses includes food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Faafetai

texts.en:
Faafetai I. is 56 and married with 6 children. She owns a business planting and harvesting taro for sale and has many years of experience in this business. Faafetai needs a loan of WST$1500 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve and expand the business.

Faafetai joined SPBD in 2007. This is her fourth loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Faafetai's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About  SPBD: Greg Casagrande founded SPBD in 2000 and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.  Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375"

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick is a 25 year-old single man. He started carpentry when he was 18 years old. As a member of Faulu Kenya, he has been motivated to work hard in his business which has improved since he took out a loan of 20,000 KES.  At least, he can now afford to pay his two employees. Patrick has requested a loan of 40, 000 KES to buy wood to make furniture. He hopes to stabilize his business in five years.

loans.use: To buy wood to make furniture

loans.name: Billiah

texts.en:
Billiah A. M. supplies building materials. Her business is located at Mtopanga area in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attractions, not forgetting the Indian Ocean's white beaches. 

Billiah has been selling such building items as sand, ballast, and coral blocks for the last ten years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is having to work hard to win the hearts of customers since she is in a business which is male dominated. 

Billiah works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more sand, ballast and coral blocks to meet the demand of her customers. She hopes to be a supplier of her goods in future. She also hopes to own a lorry to help her transport the building materials. She describes herself as very determined. 

Billiah is married to a contractor and a mother of four, aged between seventeen years old and five years old.

loans.use: Sand, Ballast, Coral Blocks.

loans.name: Nina's Group

texts.en:
Nina B. is leader of this group. She is fifty-five and divorced. She lives alone. She is a teacher at the local school and she also makes additional money through selling rolls and buns that she makes herself. She started her business of making and selling rolls and buns with an initial investment 1,000 soms. Now, she earns 10,500 soms by making and selling rolls and buns. She wants to increase her turnover and buy some equipment therefore she has applied for a loan. In the future, she is planning to buy furniture for her house and a new refrigerator. 

Group members:

- Gulnara A. is treasurer of this group. She is thirty-nine and divorced. She has a five-year-old son. He goes to kindergarten “Kelechek”. She is a teacher at the local school. Also, she provides additional courses for interested students and sells children’s books. On the profits from additional sources, she could provide for her son. Now she is planning to increase her turnover therefore she has applied for a loan. Also, she is planning to start cattle breeding in order to make additional money. In the near future, she is planning to open a book shop and make some repairs at her house.

Malik R. is twenty-six and single. He is a teacher at the local school. He also breeds cattle. He started cattle breeding upon the suggestion of a friend. He started cattle breeding two years ago with initial investment of 10,000 soms. Now, he makes 800 soms on cattle breeding. With the profits from cattle breeding he provides for his mother. There is a decrease in the price of cattle therefore he wants to purchase more cattle now. Unfortunately, he doesn’t have sufficient funds, so he applied for a loan. He plans to fatten and resell the cattle at a higher price. With the profits received from cattle breeding, he plans to buy a car and save some money for his wedding. 

- Tatiana K. is fifty-eight and married. Her husband is a car mechanic. Also, he sells car parts at the shop that is located at the car repair shop.  With the help of her husband, Tatiana breeds cattle. They started cattle breeding fifteen years ago with an initial investment of 3,500 soms. Their monthly income from cattle breeding is 9,000 soms. With the profits from cattle breeding and the car shop, they bought furniture and household appliances. They are applying for a loan in order to buy car parts to increase their turnover in the shop and purchase cattle for breeding. In the future with the profits from their business, she is planning to buy a flat. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: purchasing food production equipment

loans.name: Abibatu

texts.en:
This is 35-year-old Abibatu. She is married and has two children, aged 8 and 14 years. In 2005, Abibatu established her gara (dyed fabric) materials business. She began her business because she knew it from childhood. Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about 1200000 Sierra Leone leones (Le) every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Abibatu requires a loan in order to add more stock and buy raw materials for her business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 250,000. In the future, Abibatu plans to establish a savings account and educate her children with part of her profit to support her husband. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials to produce clothing

loans.name: Thank You Jesus Group

texts.en:
Isatu K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Isatu was born in Makeni city about thirty-two years ago. She is married to a soldier and the couple has five children, two in secondary school and three in primary school.

For twenty years now, Isatu has been selling market food – palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), salt, Maggi (cubes used to give sauce a sweet taste), and poultry. This is the second loan that  Isatu and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this new loan, they will be able to further expand their businesses, make more sales and further improve their living conditions. 

Isatu will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to expand her business; she will buy palm oil, salt, Maggi cubes and poultry in large quantity to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy palm oil, salt, Maggi and poultry in large quantity

loans.name: Galilaya Group

texts.en: Beatrice J. is in her late thirties and is married with one daughter. Five years ago, she opened her own beauty salon. She also sells kanga (sarongs) and kitenge (fabrics) that are used as women's clothing. Her business is open daily between 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. and earns Beatrice a good monthly profit. This will be Beatrice's first loan with Kiva partner Tujijenge Tanzania. Beatrice aims to increase her inventory of kanga and kitenge, as well as buy equipment for her beauty salon. Beatrice will share this loan with her loan group, Galilaya, which totals 16 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loan. In the picture, Beatrice can be seen in the second row, first on the right.

loans.use: To increase inventory of kanga and kitenge (sarongs and fabrics)

loans.name: Myagmardorj

texts.en:
Myagmardorj L.  lives with his wife and teenage daughter in an apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife works in a hotel while his only daughter attends a local high school.  The family rents an apartment with monthly fees of 250,000 MNT and pays the rent every 6 months. Myagmardorj used to work in his brother's vacuum window making company and in 2004, he decided to operate his own window-making business with the help of his friend, in a rented workplace, renting the necessary equipment. 

After years of operation, they were able to buy their own tools and equipment and run their business which however stopped in 2009 due to high rental cost. After that, Myagmardorj  purchased a container space in Narantuul, the biggest market in the city, where he operates a luggage-storing business. He has built up a stable and successful operation within this short period. Over the year of operation, his earnings have enabled him to live in a rented apartment after previously living in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent, in his brother's yard. 

Myagmardorj is a modest and helpful man . He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to expand his business type by returning to his previous vacuum window-producing business.

loans.use: To return his vacuum window-producing business

loans.name: Yhovana

texts.es: La Sra. Yhovana vive en la zona del Plan 3000 en el Barrio Suarez, hace 3 años que viven allí en alquiler, ellos se dedican  la confección de gorras, cuentan con máquinas industriales y rectas,  trabajan a pedido de serigrafías muy reconocidas en la ciudad. Ellos tienen una hija de 3 añitos que cuidan mientras están en casa confeccionando las gorras,  es la segunda oportunidad que ellos acceden a un crédito en Emprender ya que esta vez necesitan el dinero para invertir en materiales para la confección de las gorras como ser: telas, entretelas, botones, scrach, viceras e hilos, además de invertir también en un puesto en el mercado de la zona que les servirá para vender directamente sus gorras sin tener que entregar a intermediarios ya que ellos todos los días desde muy temprano están confeccionando y trabajando hasta muy tarde para entregar los pedidos que les hacen. Ellos se caracterizan por ser responsables y cumplidos, esperan poder comprar pronto un lote para poder luego construir su casa, asimismo ampliar su taller y poder contar con operarios  más máquinas.
texts.en:
Yhovana lives in Plan 3000 district in the Suarez neighborhood.  She has lived there for 3 years in a rental house.  She has a business making caps and has industrial and straight-line sewing machines.  She makes silk-screen printings to order which are very well known in the town.  She has a 3 year-old daughter who she looks after while she is in the house making caps.

This is the second time that she has taken a loan from Emprender.  On this occasion she needs money to invest in materials to make caps such as fabrics, inner linings, buttons, visors and thread.  She would also like to invest in a market stall in the area which will help her to sell her caps directly without having to deliver them to intermediaries.  She works every day from very early in the morning until very late to deliver the orders which she has.  She is a very responsible and courteous woman who hopes to soon be able to buy a lot where she can build her house.  She would also like to expand her workshop and be able to afford more machines for her workers.

loans.use: To buy supplies, fabrics and buttons

loans.name: Matilde

texts.es:
Matilde tiene 56 años de edad, es casada y reside junto a su familia en el Anexo Barrio Muro del Caserío Tranca Sasape, una zona rural ubicada en el distrito de Mórrope, una zona de pobladores humildes que suelen dedicarse a la agricultura y al comercio, pertenece a la provincia de Lambayeque y se encuentra situada a mas de una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a la crianza y venta de animales menores. Ella aves como gallinas, patos y pavos al aire libre cerca de su vivienda, las suele alimentar de granos y pastos naturales. Cuando estas aves ya han alcanzado un buen nivel de desarrollo las ofrece en venta a los negociantes que suelen visitar la zona y al público en general. Adicionalmente cuenta con un pequeño taller de costura en su vivienda en donde suele confeccionar diversas prendas para damas y caballero en base a pedidos. Con estos ingresos ella se encarga de colaborar con el sostenimiento diario de su familia.

Matilde desea adquirir alimento balanceado para sus animales ya que desea que estos se desarrollen de mejor modo para que sean vendidos a un mejor precio, sobretodo durante la temporada navideña que es cuando la demanda aumenta. Por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles.

Ella es una mujer bastante hogareña y trabajadora. En la imagen nos muestra su pequeño taller de confección.
texts.en:
Matilde is 56 years old.  She is married and lives together with her family in Barrio Muro annex of Tranca Sasape, a rural area of Mórrope district.  This is an area of unassuming people who usually work in agriculture and commerce.  It is in Lambayeque province, more than an hour from the city of Chiclayo.

Matilde raises and sells young animals.  She raises hens, ducks and turkeys in the open air near her home.  She usually feeds her birds on grain and natural fodder.  When they have reached a good level of development she offers them for sale to the traders who usually visit her area and also to the general public.  Matilde also has a small sewing workshop in her home where she makes different garments for men and women to order.  With this income she contributes to the daily support of her family.

Matilde would like to acquire basic feed for her animals since she would like them to develop as well as possible so that she can sell them for a good price, particularly during this Christmas period which is when demand increases.  For this reason, she is requesting a loan for 1,500 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

Matilda is a home-loving and hard-working woman.  In the photo she shows us her small dressmaking workshop.

loans.use: To buy balanced feed to improve her business raising and selling animals

location.town: Anexo Barrio Muro - Tranca Sasape - Mórrope - Lamb

loans.name: Maria Brendy

texts.en:
Maria is fifty-years old.  She lives in the village of El Portidor in the district of Las Lomas, a semi-tropical zone primarily populated by farmers and ranchers.  The majority of the population manages small fruit plantations or raises animals.  Maria owns her home (in which she appears in the photo) and she shares it with her husband and their dependent son.

Out of the front of her home, Maria operates a small general store.  She sells basic items such as food, dry goods, hygienic supplies and candy.  She attends to her loyal clients on a daily basis, seven days a week.  She is happy to be able to serve her community and improve their access to such items.  Maria’s husband is a professor who earns a consistent income that provides for the majority of the family’s expenses.

Maria plans to use the loan to expand her selection and deepen her inventory so that she can better meet the demands of her clients during the holiday season.  This will be her first loan with Kiva's partner, Edpyme Alternativa.  She hopes to be able to increase her market share and the number of clients she has by improving her inventory and service.  In this manner she expects that she will be able to solidify the business, earn additional income for the family and proviD. for a more stable future.

loans.use: To expand her selection and increase her inventory so that she can meet the demands of her clients during the holiday season

loans.name: Luís Enrique

texts.es:
Luís Enrique L. C. tiene 42 años. Vive en Unión Libre, vive con la conviviente y con los hijos, vive en el cantón de Chillanes en la Provincia de Bolívar. Tiene 4 hijo.

Los miembros de la V.R.C. LA ESPERANZA NUNCA SE PIERDE, pertenece a la comunidad o recinto el Placer, a una distancia de 120 minutos de la oficina en Chillanes, los miembros de esta ventanilla en su mayoría se dedican a la agricultura.

Luis se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, cacao, arroz. Las compras y ventas las realiza en el Cantón Chillanes en la feria de los días Domingos.

Solicita el crédito para la comprar de semillas, abonos, fertilizantes. Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentan desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es tener una buena cosecha para tener mas ingresos económicos para dar la educación a los hijos.

Le gusta ver la televisión, escuchar música y hacer deporte.
texts.en:
Luís Enrique L. C., 42, lives in a common law relationship with his partner and children in Chillanes canton, Bolívar province.  He has 4 children.

The members of the LA ESPERANZA NUNCA SE PIERDE (HOPE IS NEVER LOST) communal bank are from the community of Placer which is 120 minutes from the Chillanes office; they are for the most part farmers.

Luis is a corn, cocoa bean and rice farmer.  He makes both his purchases and his sales in Chillanes canton’s market on Sundays.

He is asking for a loan to buy seed, manure and fertilizers.  Support from the loan will help him economically to meet his needs.  They face challenges like infestations, illnesses and climactic variations.  His dream is to have a good harvest and earn more income to give his children a good education.

He likes to watch television, listen to music and play sports.

loans.use: For seed, manure and fertilizers.

loans.name: Jorge Nicolás

texts.es:
Jorge Nicolás S. S., tiene 32 años, es casado vive con su esposa en el Cantón Ventanas Provincia de los Ríos. Tiene 3 hijos de diferentes edades 

Los miembros de la V.R.C. CIUDADELA LOS ANGELES se encuentra ubicada en el recinto Los Ángeles, pertenece al Cantón Ventanas, esta ventanilla de 14 miembros se dedica a las labores agrícolas en ciclo corto de siembra de maíz, arroz.

Jorge Nicolás se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, Compra sus productos en  Farma - Agro y vende en el mismo lugar.

Solicita el crédito para sembrar maíz, compra de insumos y semillas. Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentar desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es ser un Buen Profesional.

Le gusta hacer amigos y ser sociable.
texts.en:
Jorge Nicolás S. S. is 32. He is married and lives with his wife in the Ventanas Canton, Los Rios province. He has 3 children of different ages.
The members of the V.R.C. Ciudadela Los Angeles are located in the Los Angeles district, belonging to the Ventanas Canton. The 14 members of this community bank work in short-cycle agriculture sowing corn and rice.
Jorge Nicolas works in agriculture sowing corn. He purchases his products in Farma-Agro and sells in the same location.
He is requesting this loan for sowing corn and purchasing supplies and seeds. The support of this loan will help him economically to supply his needs. He confronts challenges such as plagues, diseases and the varied climate. His dream is to be a good professional.
He enjoys making friends and being social.

loans.use: the purchase of supplies and seeds

loans.name: Zagdsambuu

texts.en:
Zagdsambuu, 31, is married and lives with his wife and two year old daughter in Songino-Hairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, a capital of Mongolia.  He had an employment contract between Mongolia and South Korea which allowed him to gain experience working in Korea.  

When he returned to his home country, he started a food trading business.  He opened a grocery store where his wife helps him operate the food shop. Zagdsaambuu mostly does the food purchasing for the store and also drives a taxi.  While working in Korea, he gained a lot experience about how to operate a business as well as financial responsibility.  He wants to enlarge his current store by next year.  He is a hardworking man with a lot of initiative.  He is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT so he can purchase more grocery products for his business since he now lacks adequate working capital.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda is a married woman who lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures: a general store,  the retail of rice and a gasoline retail business. Her husband Vernie, who is 26 years old, works as a driver of motorcycle to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 3 children who are 1 mos to 6 years old. 

Florenda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2010 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 2 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Florenda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 7000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8000,  uplifting the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her 3 cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 12000, which she intends to use to pay for more purchase more stock to sell so that she could continue to save up for future family needs. Florenda is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the  NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more green bananas to sell to her customers

loans.name: Monina

texts.en: Monina is a married woman who lives in Bogo, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband Eldefonso, who is 48 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living.  They have two children who are 20 and 22 years old. Monina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2010 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her first loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Monina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 5,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her second loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy stock for the general store so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business. Monina is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more products to sell

loans.name: G.s. Manos Unidas Group

texts.es: La señora Flor de Maria se dedica a su negocio que es la venta de nacatamales y cosas de horno. Obtiene ingresos adicionales en su familia del ingreso de su esposo que trabaja como albañil por cuenta propia. El préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de materia prima para la elaboración de nacatamales, no tiene mucha competencia ya que vende de manera ambulante. Su próximo paso es establecer una venta de fritangas en su casa, pretende lograrlo con ahorros obtenidos de las ganancias del préstamo. En un futuro continuara invirtiendo en su negocio en la compra de cerdos. Marta Lizette tiene 37 años de edad, es casada, su esposo es chofer de un microbús. El obstáculo más grande ha sido la venta y elaboración de pan. Invirtió el crédito en la compra de harina, huevos, mantequilla, queso, bolsas,  entre otros.
texts.en:
Flor de Maria works at her business that sells nacatamales and baked goods.  She wants to earn additional income for her family to add to her husband's.  He works as a self-employed bricklayer.  

The loan will be invested in the purchase of materials to make nacatamales.  She does not have much competition because she sells her products on the street.  Her next step is to establish a fried snack stand at her home.  She plans to do this with the savings from the income from the loan.  In the future, she will continue investing in the business of purchasing pigs.  

Marta Lizette is 37 years old, married, and her husband drives a minibus.  The biggest obstacle she faces is the sale and making of bread.  She will invest the loan in the purchase of flour, eggs, butter, cheese, and other items.

loans.use: to buy flour, eggs, butter, cheese, and other items.

loans.name: Evelia

texts.es:
Evelia tiene 29 años de edad, es casada y tiene 3 hijos. Vive en casa propia en el caserío  La Mónicas en el distrito de Tambogrande, una zona agrícola situada en la región Piura, a más de cuatro horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.
